response: Schools can support students in learning how to utilize and navigate productive online tools such as googledocs to support their collaboration.

I would advise her to create a task force of teachers who successfully use social media to lead professional developments for other teachers as a way to support engaging lessons through social media. Then she should gather a group of students and have them craft a student Rights and Responsibilities document that outlines what appropriate behavior is online at school. Then a meeting with parents to develop parent leaders who can educate other parents about how the school is using online access to support students' education.

i would absolutely talk to the girls who posted hurtful comments online.  i would take screen shots of the comments and call the parents of all of the girls, so that they could see what type of online behavior their children were engaged in and possibly discuss how to monitor it better.  i would hope that they would apologize to each other and reflect on what they had done.  i would also require that the post be removed.  i would then use this as an opportunity to teach more about cyber bullying, the consequences of it, and the long term unintended effects on all parties involved.

I would tell her that those are very valid concerns... and that maintaining quality education should be her number one priority... as well as the safety of her students.  that being said, i would also tell her that it is partly the school's responsibility to develop socially conscious and responsible online citizens. to do that i would suggest instituting a policy that provided ample opportunity for students to engage in authentic online contexts so that they could practice 21st century skills that would develop a positive and productive digital identity.  I would also suggest that this policy could not be implemented without some serious commitment to quality training for teachers, that would allow them to integrate such technology policies in their classrooms.

No\nLike any other language, texting is a form of word play and practice. It allows one to be creative and manipulate (master) certain forms of the language depending on the situational context. What texting IS DOING is making it harderFor kids (and adults!!!) to build and practice those other important communication functions. For example, the ability to read and write in the increasingly important language of empathy and perspective taking. It also is creating barriers to really important traditional communication modes. Like reflective inner dialogue. And introspective rest. Texting is not the devil, but it is a practice we should scrutinize and study more to minimize the possible adverse affects.

Procon.org, How Stuff Works, Wikipedia\nI've used all of these websites and find them credible enough for basic academic research. They are all designed to inform the public about specific topics. Minimal risks, but also minimal benefits\nOur school district has this and it is not enough, some of the most interesting and potentially educational videos are not on the YouTube education site.  it is similar to the list of banned books that schools historically and currently have disallowed from being in school libraries.  the beauty and danger of the internet is that it is open and bountiful with ALL types of information.  the purpose of education is to question this and be informed about the multiple perspectives and types of information that is now available to us via the web.  hard to do when a majority of it is being censored and blocked.

Teachers, Parents, Students who use social media for academic research, School Administrators (such as principals, superintendants and school committee members)\nTrying to keep in mind that designing policy that impacts many people requires you to look at the majority and most general groups of stakeholders at the outset... and then get more specific as the policy uncovers the needs of other groups you perhaps had not considered before. the school district is responsible for having students, teachers, parents, and administrators engage in the process of education.  the other groups are important but not the central mission of the school district.  so the policy has to address the central mission first.

i would totally invite Jason to participate in any event.  the more different people the more opportunities for fun.  i do think that social media can help reinforce stereotypes that we buy into about certain groups of people.  for example, searching up certain high schools in youtube leads you to playlists of student created videos of fights.  this reinforces that young people are cruel, violent, and basically don't care...yet at the very same time you have social media and the internet in general helping young people and older folks alike to BREAK DOWN stereotypical barriers that lock us into certain ways of thinking about diverse groups in society.  social media can be a way to learn about people and cultures different to you, by directly interacting with them online.

I chose to follow people based on a couple of factors. 1) content they post. Whether its original posts like photos, or reposts like articles and stories 2) extended network. who they follow. If their network looks diverse and open minded then that ups the chances ill follow. 3) interaction. How they present themselves. Comments they leave or things they "like". 4) aligned interests. If I'm personally interested in what they have to say to the world, if it is something il already interested in or that I'm curious about. These are guidelines and not hard and steady rules. I have definitely followed someone out of guilt for following me. Or because I had a relationship with them in the past and feel obligated now. But for the most part you have to fall into those categories.

Tumblr, Facebook, YouTube / Vimeo, Google+ / Hangouts / Google Groups, Instagram\nalthough many of these sites are blocked (for unknown or unspecified reasons to those who decided to block them i suspect) many students have figured out with ease how to bypass the firewall blocking in order to access them anyway. as an educator i can't count the number of times i have wanted to utilize some online resource only to have it blocked and the teacher bypass not functioning quite the way i need it to.  there are a lot of improvements that could be made to our district's policy.

Parents and teenagers have different goals and different ways of viewing relationships and communication.  I know that as a teen I wanted nothing to do with my parents in a social context.  They were a means to an end (i know that sounds harsh... love ya mom) but they provided me my basic needs and then set up rules.  They did not meet my social needs.  That is what my friends were for.  For example, they would be the ones telling me what time i had to return from the party and not the people at the party i would be socializing with.  In that sense, teenagers have a developmental need to form their OWN identity apart from their parents.  Their whole life up until that point as been largely, if not entirely formed by their parents.  Teenage years are the time when the brain starts ttellingl you to make your own friends, choose your own interests, etc.  So that is probably why she denied her mother's friend request. As a parent now, i understand the desire to want to be involved in your child's life, as much as possible, for safety (physical and emotional) as well as continuing to support their development and just enjoying life with them.  However, as a teacher i do recognize the importance of letting go, providing autonomy to young people as they try and navigate THEIR life, using THEIR capabilities, talents, and the likes.  So, as a parent i would not take offense TOO much to this.

Strategies for managing online safety and privacy practices should be taught, not ignored by schools.\nThe concepts of privacy are very important online and off, and that is a lesson needed to be taught.Social media encourages us to almost relentlessly self-promote, but often without the thought of consequences.

Schools aren't obliged to provide easy, unrestricted access to the internet. There is a lot of content that is unquestionably inappropriate for students. I do think access to content unquestionably appropriate for students should be provided. I think it boils down to what internet based resources can be identified as academically beneficial. I do think teachers are the best judge of what can and should be used to help them teach. That takes planning, and a critical eye.

Since this question is looking for a named individual who invented something, I'm going to answer with what I found by searching "first flushing toilet patent".I got an about.com link that claims Alexander Cummings first patented the flushing toilet in Britian in 1775.http://inventors.about.com/od/pstartinventions/a/Plumbing_3.htmThey don't cite where they got their info, and that does bother me. This is a good example of an article that can spread bad information.

Procon.org, Wikipedia\nProcon and Wikipedia have cited many, many other sources in their article, and at first glance I would consider them more trustworthy than how stuff works, which only cites a couple external sources.But to really consider how trustworthy these articles are I would need to also consider all those sources that have been cited in the article.I also know that wikipedia has a very active community of editors, and I do think information found there is frequently scrutinized. If you click the talk tab of the article linked, you'll find a large amount of history about the article, including that it is considered "peer reviewed" according to wikipedia standards.

For me, there isn't a conscious act of going online. I carry a cell phone which receives emails immediately. Our home phone is VOIP and therefore always connected to the internet. Normally, our household is listening to internet streaming music, and in the evenings, we might choose something to watch on demand. Most of our internet usage is based around the household, once we go out, I don't use as many services.When at home, I do pick up a laptop (or sit at a desktop if it's more convenient) about 5 times a day, for up to 15 minutes at a time. During that time, I'm checking my favorites, mostly dynamic feeds or news aggregators.

response: Teachers, Parents, School Administrators (such as principals, superintendants and school committee members)\nI chose parents, teachers, and school administrators.I chose administrators because it included committee members. But I don't think superintendents or principals should be making decisions alone.I think parents and teachers can be very good advocates for those in their care. I think students should spend time talking to their their parents and teachers about school and how they think things should be. I left the types of students in the list out of my choices because the scenarios described all have better alternatives. Social media is not the best source for academic research. If research is being done on social media, then a case could be made for access, but then it might also be granted for a specific project with a specific scope.Internet access is not synonymous with social media access, so those students without internet at home should have internet access at school which is limited to school related content.

extremely likely\nI may use a commercial search engine like google, or bing to find some information for my research, but if I am going to cite a source, I prefer to use something printed. I think those sources have gone through more editing and review prior to publication. I also think it demonstrates more effort on my part towards my research.But because nearly all card catalogs have been replaced with electronic systems, even while finding books or articles at the library I am using a search engine much like google to find my material in the library.I also have to ask why there is a picture of a toilet being flushed as the resource image for this question???

Credit for that goes to 16th-century author Sir John Harington, who not only came up with the idea but installed an early working prototype in the palace of Queen Elizabeth I, his godmother. The first patent for a flushing water closet was issued to Alexander Cummings in 1775, sixty years before Thomas Crapper was born.The son of a Yorkshire steamboat captain, Tom Crapper's destiny was fixed when he was apprenticed to a master plumber at the age of 14. He owned his own plumbing shop in London by the time he was 25. Crapper was awarded nine patents for plumbing innovations during his lifetime, three of them consisting of improvements to the flushing water closet.Though he made his name as a sanitary engineer to bluebloods, Crapper himself was lowborn and never knighted, so it's a mystery why storytellers consistently award him the title "Sir."

Mostly risky with minimal benefits\nIf the site is focused on education, it seems like it would offer advantages while also limiting access to other channels that may be more problematic.

Obtain input from major stakeholders such as parents, teachers, students and administrators to develop a plan that addresses concerns and identifies pros and cons. Study available options for creating safer use of social media.Train teachers on how to integrate use of social media for learning purposesImplement a program to train students on appropriate and safe use of social media.

Principal Tanner should open a discussion process with students and parents as well as experts in the field to determine the pros and cons of the decision. Together these groups of stakeholders could inform the decision, which would maximize positive outcomes and collaboration by all. Also experts can offer options for how concerns about more open internet access.  Perhaps Principal Tanner can seek funding from a foundation to obtain services from a consulting group who can assess the positive and negative impacts and outcomes from the policy change. This would then help the stakeholders consider the information for any policy revisions necessary.
Yes\nSocial media has an important influence in our society and is a common way of communication. As such, teaching students about social media practices should be part of what schools do.

Online social networks will be critical to securing employment in a digital, global marketplace.\nIt is important for students to learn the potential of social media for learning about employment opportunities. I also agree with the statement that social media can be one source for student collaboration and learning. However, I also think that students need to learn and manifest appropriate use of  social media so their use does not later negatively impact employment and college opportunities.

Schools have an important role to play in closing this opportunity gap. Schools should think creatively about how to provide internet access to students within appropriate contexts and time periods while also protecting students from exposure to internet sites where they could be exploited or abused.  While social media and internet sources offer potentially valuable resources for students in research and learning, if used inappropriately they can also distract from learning. Finding the right balance and approaches is what is key.

Teachers, Victims of online bullying, Future employers, College admissions officers\nNot on the list is the needs of students themselves, which would be my first priority. Student learning and things that support learning should be top priority in the design of a social media policy.  I checked future employers and college admissions officers since training students to not use social media (unless required for their class work) during school and in job settings is part of what students need to learn to be successful in jobs and in college. I checked teachers because, assuming that teachers have student learning as a priority, their concerns are important to consider. And of course protecting students from online bullying is important as it can cause great damage.

None of these sites is blocked at my school\nI am a professor at USC and as far as I know none of the sites in the list above are blocked. I think that some of these sites should be blocked (eg Facebook) since they are not necessary for academic work. Some students go on these sites during class time. This interferes with their learning and as a professor, I find it disrespectful.  I know that when students get jobs, use of such sites for non work related purposes would reflect negatively on them. This could lead to negative evaluations by their supervisors and potentially loss of their jobs.

I'd say about 20-25%, which is a bit ironic since I'm online so much, but I prefer face-to-face interaction and talking on the phone. Texting is a great way to touch base or trade some funny thoughts, but if it's anything of any substance, I'll pick up the phone or go find them.

In looking at the way he portrays himself, it looks like he is a football player, but what seems to come across even more is that he is very religious and family means a lot to him. As someone who is not overly religious, I might be cautious until I knew for sure how he approached others with his religion. His Bible quotes make me a little uncomfortable, but that is primarily because a lot of religious people I know who quote a lot of the Bible think others should believe as they do. I do like seeing his love for his family. I would approach him with an open-mind because I see nothing that would suggest to me that he is a bad person.

I think they can do both depending on the person and situation. Inside jokes and photos can definitely make someone feel like an outsider. But sometimes, people can feel more comfortable talking with others when they have the distance that online platforms provide them....which is why it's also possible for people to say hateful things they wouldn't say online. I think overall, it's very important to think about how you want to be perceived when you interact online. As for Jason, I would welcome him and apologize to him for not including him earlier...but that's because I tend to do these things in real life, too.

It would bother me if the friend seems more engaged with whoever he/she was texting than with me. I think it can be very rude to not disconnect when you are with people. On the other hand, an occasional text wouldn't bother me. And if the friend had something going on that made it necessary to be texting, that would be okay, too, as long as the friend explained why s/he was texting so much. If it bothers me too much, I'm not afraid to say something or make a joke about it to draw attention to the behavior.

As a parent, it's a good idea to see what their kids are doing online. It's not (usually) intended to be nosy, but to be aware of any unsafe and inappropriate behaviors their children are engaging in. On the other hand, Julia probably wants some independence from her mother, which is why she ignored the request.

This is a tricky question because different kids respond differently. I certainly wouldn't retaliate by posting pictures because that just perpetuates the bad behavior and harms more people. I would estimate that I'm online 6-8 hours a day! As I type that, it sure seems like a lot, but as a university instructor it's a big part of my job. All of my grading is even online because students turn in work via Dropbox, class wikis, class Nings, and even email. Most of the time, I'm online from home, although much of my teaching time also involves going online. And when I'm not online "formally," I am often quickly popping on and offline via my phone...I can't walk from my car to campus without checking email, texts, or even Facebook.

This is another tricky question. I think that Facebook does both. On one hand, Facebook provides a space where people seem to feel more comfortable communicating with others. The awkwardness of face-to-face interaction which sometimes occurs, does not exist on the Facebook platform. However, Facebook also lends itself  to the development of cliques that exclude others. As evidence we have cyber bullying and pages that are created to "burn" someone.

This is a tricky question. I think it depends on the situation. If I am out to meet someone so that we can catch up over coffee, lunch, dinner I think that phones should be put away. It is rude and inconsiderate to be sending text messages when you're supposed to be chatting with a friend. However, in my daily life I often find myself needing to communicate with others while I'm engaged in other activities. My husband is also constantly using his phone because of work. However, we make it a point not to use our phones during dinner time. I think you need to establish a time to disconnect with social media and connect with people face-to-face.

Yes\nStudents should be help liable if they are threatening or bullying other students through social media outside of school. Obviously this is an example of technology being ahead of our policies and procedures but at the end of the day any harassing or bullying speech that impacts the school campus should be addressed and closely monitored in regards to the security and safety of our students

We should be able to help students have access in our classes but there are limitations of what we can provide for students. I think it is more important to give our students the skills to use these tool and it is very important for parents to prioritize to give their children access to the Internet at home
